ironic/common/neutron.py.message: This is strange usage, because pxe_enabled "Indicates whether pxe is enabled or disabled", but ramdisk can be booted via virtual media feature w/o pxe and we need plug node to provisioning/cleaning network.

I like the idea of introducing pxe_required boot interface option. Will rework this patch.

there is no need to check if port is a member of portgroup or not. pxe_enabled flag may be set to False independently and also our API doesn't allow to have wrong combinations of standalone_ports_supported on portgroup and port pxe_enabled flag.
Hm.. why IPA doesn't support bonded interfaces? I don't think IPA should care about NIC configuration, but might be I'm missing something?

I wonder if we should add pxe_required=True as a kwarg into this function to make it easier for drivers to override this check then we could have.

def standalone_port(pg_id):
    if not pg_id:
        return True
    pg = portgroups.get_by_id(pg_id)
    return pg.standalone_port_supported

available_ports = [p for p in task.ports if standalone_port(p.portgroup_id)]
available_ports = [p for p in available_ports if p.pxe_enabled or not pxe_required]

Or we could even add it as a property to the boot interface itself, e.g. 

class ILOVMediaBoot(...):

    pxe_required=False

then instead of a kwarg this function can just do:

pxe_required = task.driver.boot.pxe_required

WDYT?

The reason I added the check for portgroups is for the case when pxe_required = False because IPA currently doesn't support bonded network interfaces so even in virtual media case we need to make sure that we can use the NICs independently.

Indeed if we boot node via virtualmedia we shouldn't care here if port is pxe_enabled or not. But it is a vendor specific case, it should be fixed in ILO driver than or they shouldn't care and set pxe_enabled=True always.

For the virtual media case where we can use pxe_enabled=False NICs we need to exclude the ports that can't be used by themselves and then (in the future) think about making our ramdisks support bonding then add portgroups support to this function too.
These two lines are not needed.

test-requirements.txt.message:
We have a feature in OSCI to allow tests to refer to zaza tests using a func-test-pr: stanza in the commit message.  

i.e. you submit a PR to zaza-openstack-tests and then put

func-test-pr: https://github.com/openstack-charmers/zaza-openstack-tests/pull/292

in the commit message.  Then OSCI will use that version of zaza-openstack-tests as part of the CI run.

releasenotes/notes/ilo-refresh-firmware-.message: I'm trying to understand why or the use case, and I'm not getting that from the entry in launchpad.  Could we get an explanation of why this is useful? or how it helps an operator or user in their every day life?

At present, ``ilo_firmware_version`` and ``rom_firmware_version`` are updated as part of the node capabilities when node inspection happens. And if the operator wishes to update firmware of any of those 2 components via manual cleaning's 'update_firmware' method, then the latest updated firmware versions are not getting reflected in node capabilities. So, this patch ensures that the firmware version information is up-to-date even after updating the firmware via manual cleaning.

Please let me know if this clarifies the significance of this patch.

playbooks/roles/bifrost-ironic-install/t.message:
I'm not sure I follow the logic here.

- if the client is *not* running iPXE, tell it to boot undionly.kpxe over TFTP.
- if the client is running iPXE in EFI mode, tell it to boot /ipxe.efi over TFTP.
- if the client is running iPXE in BIOS mode, tell it to fetch boot.ipxe from the appropriate HTTP server and boot that.

Is that the intended logic? Is that what this code actually does, or am I reading it wrong?
Also, do we only want to tag a client as EFI if it's using EFI bytecode? RFC 4578 lists three other architectures with "EFI" in the name.

Reading http://ipxe.org/howto/chainloading, it looks like what I've described above isn't the intended logic - you want to send ipxe.efi iff the client is running standard PXE in EFI mode. I think you can achieve this as follows:

    dhcp-match=set:ipxe,175
    dhcp-match=set:efi,option:client-arch,7
    dhcp-boot=tag:!ipxe,tag:!efi,/undionly.kpxe
    dhcp-boot=tag:!ipxe,tag:efi,/ipxe.efi
    # code to boot clients who are using iPXE here

Will the code in lines 451 onwards handle clients running iPXE in EFI mode as-is?

/COMMIT_MSG.message:
Add option to enable/disable segment

The blueprint proposes enabling/disabling of segment so that any notifications arriving from host assigned to it can be controlled as per the operator's requirement.

The previous title was ok.

Add option to enable/disable a segment

specs/ussuri/approved/enable-to-segment..message:
The 'enable' field of segment should be returned with failover segment for which you will need to introduce a new microversion and change the related REST API like :-
1. POST /segments
2. GET /segments
3. GET /segment/<segment_uuid>

Need changes in notifications as you are adding 'enable' field in segment.
Refer to docs: https://docs.openstack.org/masakari/latest/user/notifications.html.
changes in python-masakariclient is required. Please highlight those changes here.
Please refer to the "Work Items" section from ussuri-template.rst and add the tasks here.

Please add scenario how you would like to test this feature.

for example, Create a new failover segment with enable=False, add hosts to it. Create a notification (any type) and confirm that the status of  notification is set as "IGNORED".
Add option to enable/disable a segment

For example, When we plan to update the hardware or pull the latest code on the compute nodes where the masakari-monitors are running, we are required to stop masakari-api and masakari-engine services so that it won't execute any ha recovery workflow. If you forget to stop these services, then it would end up in a mess and you will need to spend lot of your time in recovering instances which are messed up.
So, we need a simple solution which will allow masakari-api service to discard notifications for a temporarily period upon request without needing operator to stop these services.

Rephrase  as

- Add ``state`` option to a segment.  When you will create a new segment, it will be enabled by default.  State will be of two types: ACTIVE/INACTIVE.

- Allow user to modify ``state`` option using PUT /segment/<segment_uuid> API.
- Return the ``state`` in the GET /segments and GET /segments/<segment_uuid> APIs.

If a notification is received by masakari-api from a host belonging to a failover segment whose ``state`` option is set to ``INACTIVE``, then all such notifications will be discarded by masakari-api itself.

All the above API changes will be done in a new micro-version.
Add a new db column ``state``to ``failover_segments`` db table.

Following changes will be introduced in a new API micro-version.

1. POST /segments
<Add request example>
<Add response example>

2. PUT  /segments/{segment_id}
<Add request example>
<Add response example>

3. GET /segments
<Add request example>
<Add response example>


4. GET /segments/<segment_uuid>
<Add request example>
<Add response example>

Mention which notifications will be updated as well.

For example: create.segment.start, create.segment.end etc.

Refer to the existing versioned notification: https://docs.openstack.org/masakari/latest/user/notifications.html
The python-masakariclient, masakari-dashboard and openstacksdk will be updated to support ``state`` parameter of the segment in a new micro-version.

* Create a new API microversion to handle ``state`` parameter in segments.
* Add unit and functional tests
* Update API reference documentation
* Update python-masakariclient, masakari-dashboard  and openstacksdk to manage ``state`` parameter of the segment.
Add required unit and functional tests which will run in gate.
Update the api reference to include this change.
If you forget to stop these services
This spec is mainly to add an option to enable/disable a segment.
Add a new db column ``enabled`` of type ``Boolean`` with default value as ``True`` to ``failover_segments`` table.
You will need to update the version to the next higher number.

Unit tests is in the first work item. 
Because Masakari functional tests depend on openstackSDK, so I leave it the last work item. It needs to update openstackSDK to manage 'enabled' parameter of the segment.

swift/container/updater.py.message: Is the pool really needed here? I think once all the nodes that proxy suggested threw 404, there is no rush anymore, I think. The updater can iterate sequentially, with a minimal expenditure of resources.

On most account devices, the cost will be really low as it will return 404 because the DB file won't exist.

Also, if it hits a DB file, it will be on different devices, likely on different servers, so IMHO the resource impact is quite negligible.

But I don't want it to be too slow because it would delay the real work of the container-update. I also don't like the idea of a new configuration option. Maybe re-use concurrency? WDYT?

I'm bothered that updater already runs at the configured concurrency, and now you're adding this request amplification to it. Of course, you have a real experience, and I don't, but still, it's iffy. I agree about not having the extra knob.
this is potentially like... a LOT of requests right?  "nodes" in this context is all the devices in the cluster?
Yes, all devices of the account ring. That's why there is a ContextPool to limit the concurrency.

I'm a little nervous about us doing this even when the container hasn't been marked deleted, or worse yet, when the stats are non-zero. Seeing those

 Update report failed for ...

log lines seem like a pretty good signal that the operator has some cleanup that needs doing...

The problem with leaving this as-is is two or three-fold

0. The log entry is done with debug priority, so it's invisible to most simple-minded operators. They never know it's there.

1. The log is not harmless, although mostly because of the traceback. I literally have a bug outstanding about it in the RH system: they're running out of /var space. The system loops between account server and updater.

2. The operator is not capable to establishing that container can be removed and then removing it manually.

It is not related to the bug fixed here. If it is better to move it, let's discuss and change it in a separate review.

I am not sure whether we need to adjust it or not. If you feel the current position is odd, feel free to file a new bug. This needs a discussion and apparently this review is not the best place for it.

I cannot say "should" as personally I am okay with the current position. The current position was decided considering various forms including "Create Key Pair" in the key pairs panel.

Hi Akihiro
The issue will be addressed with col-sm only,but i have changed the css of question mark icon, as its crossing the top line. I will remove the change.

Hi Akihiro,
Should i create a new bug for this change?

/COMMIT_MSG.message: What is the reason for this revert?

we tried to solve the  problem here for the old clients prior to nautilus but nautilus clients thinks its v2 port and try to communicate with server and getting some warnings as shown below:

my proposal here is to make  v2 port as default and for old clients prior  to nautilus to have override for mon_host config as show we did in this ps (https://review.opendev.org/#/c/711648/).
eventually , lets move out of old clients by changing the images wherever old ceph clients are installed.

If all we care is running functional with the latest released versions of OVN/OVS, perhaps we could just use the default from the DevStack module [0][1], it's less places to update once we want to bump the OVN version. To do that we need to source the DevStack module at [2] as this patch already does and get rid of those {OVS, OVN}_BRANCH variabels from there and from this file here.

What do you think ?

[0] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/78e16c77428e071ac14fbd3727840cd6348d1e7a/devstack/lib/ovn_agent#L33

[1] https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/78e16c77428e071ac14fbd3727840cd6348d1e7a/devstack/lib/ovn_agent#L43

[2] https://review.opendev.org/#/c/735799/6/roles/configure_functional_tests/tasks/main.yaml a

The point is that functional/fullstack jobs are a bit messy. Lemme show how it works for now.

1. Zuul spawns VM, performs a few playbooks that configures the host, generates the local.conf (under stack user) and clones code to:
/home/zuul/opendev.org/openstack/devstack,neutron,ovn

2. Zuul runs this set of playbooks under 'zuul' user:
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/zuul.d/base.yaml#L12

a) configure functional jobs with ovn/ovs compilation
https://github.com/openstack/neutron/blob/master/playbooks/run_functional_job.yaml#L3

b) do devstack stack.sh (under stack user this time...) with all the thingies disabled

c) run tox -e dsvm-functional.


On stage a) we don't rally have access to generated local.conf, because it is under different users home dir (/opt/stack) instead /home/zuul... So we need to send those variables somehow, that is why I added those into ansible vars.

Hi, Michael. Just my personal puzzle: why we need to send an IP advertisement here? Previously, amphora don't send IP advertisement but it work fine. Dose this cause potential bug if we don't send an IP advertisement?

It is a performance improvement for failover. We have changed the order of booting the replacement VM in this patch, so now we will have both the old amphora and the new one booted at the same time for a short period. By forcing an advertisement here we can improve the service resumption time by letting neutron know that the new amphora is ready and should be the new target.
This breaks UDP-only LBs by writing an always-failing check to the check_scripts directory.

octavia/controller/worker/v1/tasks/ampho.message: Why we need the two method simultaneously? I think they do same thing.

One expects a list of amphora and an index into that list, the other only takes a singe amphora.
The one with the index is used in parallel flows, such that different threads will work on different amphora at the same time. To build these flows, we need to build the two branches at flow creation time, but at that point we don't know which amphora will be acted upon (I.e. the flow may create a new amphora). So, this way we can parallelize work on an arbitrary list of amphora.

This task name is misleading (only a single amp is updated) and is largely the same implementation as AmpListenersUpdate. How about inheriting from AmpListenersUpdate? As for the name, "AmpIndexListenersUpdate" to be consistent with AmphoraIndexListenersReload and others??

nit-picking ¯\_(ツ)_/¯

Are we not trusting flows to provide up-to-date data?
The pattern I've seen is adding ReloadLoadBalancer to the flow when needed. Other option is changeing "loadbalancer" param to "loadbalancer_id".

I am not trusting the in-flow update. I think it is not behaving like we think it is. I'm moving away from the "reload" tasks as I can. There is an interaction between the flow storage and the sqlalchemy session caching that I haven't stopped to figure out as we are dropping passing DB objects in flows for v2.

Really I hope at the end of these transitions (failover, v2, etc.) we can remove the "index" word and go back to only having one type. The index versions were added to enable parallel sub-flows. This removes the tasks that iterate across the amphora to do updates.

puppet-manifests/src/modules/platform/ma.message: If this gets run twice before the subcloud certificates are updated, we have a problem. How will that be prevented?

To trigger the shift_dc_root_ca::runtime, the sysinv conductor check to ensure that the new dc_root_ca is different from the existing dc_root_ca and is not empty. So it knows that a dc_root_ca is to shift and update.
The shift operation only applies to the system controller. In subcloud, it always update dc-root-ca when $dc_root_ca_crt is not empty.

----------------

-------------------------------

------------------------
<we can mention about interacting with board of directors by joining their meeting or face to face joint leadership meeting.

While your main focus as a TC member is the governance repo, 
the complete list of repos that are under the governance of the technical committee is listed in `reference/technical-committee-repos.yaml` and goes beyond that repo.

TC members should review patches in those repos too, and follow the relevant rules and ACL depending of the repos.

I would remove this paragraph. I don't think it's a big deal to review the governance patches daily. There are not many of those, and the more people wait for review, the more time it takes to merge.

TC elected members are cores on this project, and I don't think it's enough to review one in a forthnight. People should be responsible, and asking to be responsible sounds the opposite of the intent.

+1, we should reword this towards - TC as a Core member to all TC own repos[1] and be active on responding to the incoming reviews and their maintenance.

Also update heading too, something like-
 "Maintainer/Core for Governance repo"

[1] https://opendev.org/openstack/governance/src/branch/master/reference/technical-committee-repos.yaml

I would add that TC members should prepare the monthly meeting by updating the list of topics latest one week in advance. One week before the meeting, someone from the TC should send a mailing list email to the community to announce the scope of the monthly meeting. Community members can therefore attend, follow the status update, and/or ask questions.

deployment/neutron/neutron-ovs-agent-con.message: Should it be pre_start ? IIRC we need to unwire provider bridges before OVS agent is started
I should have read the commit message first :) This will not work in case a node shuts down unexpectedly leaving the wiring in the DB and after node is started, it will cause an arp storm.

good point.
WDYT if duplicating this as well for the pre-start command and just prey for idempotency Gods?
fixed. Not pre start, but just an extra hook to have the most of the work done *before* stopping it, but also leaving the original start up script intact - as the mitigation for corner cases.
note that these two were originally missing in the commands args!

One other thing is how is this gonna work during the updates. When we turn off control plane (OVS agent), data plane should keep working. This may destroy the patch ports meaning no provider networks will work.

> ...during the updates. When
 > we turn off control plane (OVS agent), data plane should keep working. This may destroy the patch ports meaning no provider networks will work.

Could you clarify? How changing the order of stop -> destroy -> start executed by paunch during minor updates would be different (by the dataplane impact) from destroy -> stop -> (destroy idempotently) -> start ?

I don't think there are cases when we keep neutron ovs agent container down for the longer time but when we do with the only purpose of restarting is ASAP?

Indeed, I didn't think about that!
Perhaps some magic needed for that hook in the systemd unit to differentiate stop vs restart actions...

Maybe you're right. I just wanted to bring it up for the discussion - we have a code that checks for canary flow and cleans patch ports only if the flow is missing. So calling it on "stop" won't mind.

I don't know though why would you want to call this on stop as the script was mean for specific corner case when node was taken down ungracefully.

> I don't know though why would you want to call this on stop as the
 > script was mean for specific corner case when node was taken down
 > ungracefully.

That move stems from an assumption that the remove-ports script may take time, like tens of seconds on a loaded system maybe. And that that might also happen for some cases not only limited to the abrupted shutdown. Then it would introduce an extended delay for the neutron ovs agent startup. I naively assumed that brings downtime for dataplane. So I assumed that moving whatever stuff that script does to the pre-stop action instead of pre-start. I may be totally wrong though and nothing impacts dataplane even if the script is busy while the agent container stays down.

nit: i get the intend e.g. if the cache and isntance dirs are on the same mount on the host they both compete for the disk space aviabley which is reported to placment as local_GB.

but the phrasing implies to me at least that the cache image would also use the same amound of space as the instance flavor root disk which is not true.

i could be reading into that a bit too much but
depending no the file type and image setting the image in the cache can be either a raw image or a qcow image and similarly the instance disk can be a raw image or a qcow image.

so worst case if both are raw images, the cache image should be the size of the image in glance and the instance image will be the size of the flavor root disk.

if we use a qcow backing files in the cache then its size on disk could be smaller then the virtual size listed for the image assuming we do not preallocate it and similarly if we have a qcow image for the vm that uses the cache image as a backing file the overall used space on disk can be quite small.

so just confirming you wanted to imply that they are both consumign the same resouce (local disk) on the host and in plamcent and not that the cached image will be the same size as the flavor root disk.
FWIW, even after reading your assessment, I can't read the sentence here as anything implying any relation between image and flavor root disk size.

so should it be moved under the rally/rally-plugins/netcreate/netcreate?

Yes. For metadata there will be only one metadata agent in nova which is created when overcloud is deployed. But neutron creates metadata proxy for each network created. In this test for each VM you are spawning a network. So the purpose of the test is 
1) how much time neutron is taking to spawning this proxy
2) how much time neutron is taking to add ovs flows for supporting metadata

When we try to measure this at scale (2000 VMs), our scenario should be simple and that is the reason I am suggesting wait_for_ssh is sufficient. 

We use none of the rally scenarios for functional testing. That is the reason I am not convinced with nova_boot_retrieve_instance_info scenario. We need a proper use case (scale and performance) to have the scenario.
Can you split this patch into 2 patches. I am still not convinced why we need nova_boot_retrieve_instance_info scenario.

manila/share/drivers/netapp/dataontap/cl.message:
You can call the _get_licenses() method from line 189 after this. 

Something like this:

   if self._have_cluster_creds is True:
       self._set_cluster_info()
       self._licenses = self._get_licenses()
   else:
       LOG.debug('License info not available without cluster credentials')
       self._licenses = []

Actually, get_licenses need to be called in the else too.
So we can just always call:

self._licenses = self._get_licenses()

since '_get_licenses() also checks the cluster creds.
Move this into the _get_licenses() method on line 189

I don't know, I prefer letting the method only retrieving licenses, not setting configs. If someday we decide to let the admin configure this capability (e.g. force disabled), will be weird to have it inside get_licenses().

Right now, with this change, there'll are two separate calls to the backend to get licenses; one due to line you're adding: 149 and one here... 

So remove this get_licenses call from here, and move it to do_setup as suggested above.

Neither this method, nor _start_periodic_tasks() makes sense in "check_for_setup_error" - this driver routine is to validate any config issues.. But, I don't expect you to move _start_periodic_tasks in this change. Lets treat that as an orthogonal issue..
So you can move lines 268-289 here; and simplify the whole thing.

It is not impossible though (I quickly tested with ontap 9.6), but an improbable edge case to have an important volume with name 'fake' and an empty named snapshot in production.

More safeguarding here would be overkill, I guess.

Hmmm, good point. Felipe, can you use a more random fake volume name, e.g.:

 "fake_%s" % uuidutils.generate_uuid().replace("-", "_")

So it might be better to raise an exception in L289 instead of returning True.

It will crash the driver, and let the operator check what's happening, instead of reporting that it has the license applied (which might be wrong).
